message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation of vomiting and hypotension are seen in Mallory-Weiss tears, which occur from forceful retching or vomiting. A tear involving the mucosa and submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction, as seen in the endoscopy, is consistent with Mallory-Weiss tear. Boerhaave syndrome is a complete rupture of the esophagus and is unlikely in this case as the tear is only involving the mucosa and submucosa. Gastric ulcer and hiatal hernia may cause epigastric tenderness, but they wouldn't result in a tear at the gastroesophageal junction.

Boerhaave syndrome is a full thickness transmural laceration of the esophagus caused by forceful vomiting, while gastric ulcer typically presents with epigastric pain and is less likely to cause hypotension. Hiatal hernia is a protrusion of the stomach through the diaphragm into the chest and is not typically associated with vomiting blood.
